statement:
Any Krull valuation $|\cdot|$ of a field $K$ determines a unique
valuation domain $R = \{a\in K: \,\,|x|\leqq 1\}$, whose field of
fraction is $K$.

[*Proof.*]{} We first see that $1\in R$ since $|1| = 1$. Let then
$a,\,b$ be any two elements of $R$. The non-archimedean triangle
inequality shows that $|a-b| \leqq \max\{|a|,\,|b|\} \leqq 1$, i.e. that
the difference $a-b$ belongs to $R$. Using the 4 of inequalities we
obtain $$|ab| = |a|\cdot|b| \leqq 1\cdot 1 = 1$$ which shows that also
the product $ab$ is element of $R$. Thus, $R$ is a subring of the field
$K$, and so an integral domain. Let now $c$ be an arbitrary element of
$K$ not belonging to $R$. This implies that $1 < |c|$, whence
$|c^{-1}| = |c|^{-1} < 1$ (see the 5). Consequently, the inverse
$c^{-1}$ belongs to $R$, and we conclude that $R$ is a valuation domain.
The $a = \frac{a}{1}$ and $c = \frac{1}{c^{-1}}$ make evident that $K$
is the field of fractions of $R$.
